B. Sixty-five per cent of the above mentioned group listened on AH
radio for the first two surveys. Eighty-eight per cent listened on
AM for survey #3. This might lead the reader to conclude that
the increase in AH listenership was due to a decrease in EM
listenership. However, the fact that the number of EM listeners
remained the same while the total number of listeners increased
would suggest that this increase was a functioning of a gain in
AM listeners. Approximately the same number of homes continued to
listen on Eli radio; 9% of the homes reached listened on EM radio
during all three surveys.
C. The 28% of the population on surveys #1 and #2 listened to WOUI an
average of hours and Iu2 hours. The 72% on survey #3 listened to
WOUB an average of 15*6 hours per week. This was a sizable increase.
It was first felt that the fact that WOUB had increased its broadcast
hours would be an influencing factor; however, WOUI had increased
its broadcast schedule from 10 hours a day to 16 hours per day after
survey #1 and no increase in audience or listening time was
experienced on survey #2, It must be reiterated at this time that
the novelty of a new local broadcast operation combined with a well
received radio signal, comparatively good programming and locally
featured programming probably acted as a listening stimulant.
III. The ownership of EM radios did not vary appreciably from survey to
survey. The figure remained within the 25-28% catagory. 33% of
the respondents who owned EM sets listened to WCUI-EM. 80% of the
non-TV set owners listened to WOUB for an average of 16.8 hours per
week. This is slightly higher than the average of TV set owners.
